unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about what to do in a medical emergency in India? Well, first things first, memorize the emergency number: 102 for ambulance, or 100 for the police. Knowing that can literally be a lifesaver. If someone's having a heart attack, like clutching their chest and struggling to breathe, or if they’ve had a serious accident like a fall from their scooty on Linking Road, don't waste time trying home remedies. Get them to the nearest hospital, ASAP.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about what to do in a medical emergency in India? Well, first things first, memorize the emergency number: one hundred and two for ambulance, or one hundred for the police. Knowing that can literally be a lifesaver. If someone is having a heart attack, like clutching their chest and struggling to breathe, or if they have had a serious accident like a fall from their scooty on Linking Road, don't waste time trying home remedies. Get them to the nearest hospital, A-S-A-P.

unnormalised: Time is absolutely critical. If you suspect a stroke, look for drooping face, arm weakness, or speech difficulty. We call it "FAST" - Face, Arms, Speech, Time. Every minute counts, getting them to a stroke-ready hospital like AIIMS can drastically improve their chances. Try to stay calm - I know, easier said than done. But freaking out won't help anyone. Keep the person comfortable, and if they are unconscious, make sure their airway is clear.

unnormalised: Also, if someone's having a severe allergic reaction, like after eating something they shouldn’t have, and they have an EpiPen, use it! Follow the instructions carefully. Even if they seem better after the shot, still get them checked out by a doctor, Dr. Sharma at City Hospital is really good. Anaphylaxis can be tricky. And make sure you tell the doctors about any medications they're on, like if they are diabetic and taking insulin or something.

unnormalised: Finally, download a reliable first aid app on your phone. Seriously, do it now. You never know when you might need to quickly look up CPR instructions or how to handle a burn. And remember, you're not a substitute for a trained medical professional. These are just basic steps to take until help arrives. Be safe out there, ya!
